  • Points of Interest

  • Roads
  • Trails
  • Parking

Places Tracing Guide

National Park Service

About Places

Places is an internal data collection system for the National Park Service's "core" geospatial data. We built Places so that all National Park Service employees, both technical and non-technical, can contribute their knowledge to the map.

Data from Places is fed directly into both Park Tiles and the larger National Park Service structured data initiative, which will be used to drive NPS.gov and a publicly-available application programming interface (API) starting in January of 2016.

The Places database currently contains the following datasets (a near real-time copy of each can be downloaded from the Places information page):

  • Points of Interest
  • Buildings
  • Roads
  • Trails
  • Parking Lots

These datasets were initially seeded from existing park, region, and program-level GIS datasets, but now anyone who is connected to the National Park Service network can edit them using the Places Editor (NPS-only). If you have more/better data available and you'd like to get it into Places, send us an email or create an issue on GitHub and we will be happy to assist with the upload.

Disclaimer: All data contributed to Places is public-facing. Do not add any sensitive information unfit for public consumption. Only add data inside park boundaries.

The Places editor is built on top of OpenStreetMap's iD editor. Check out learnOSM's iD editor walkthrough to familiarize yourself with the interface. It is intentionally simple, developed with a non-technical audience in mind.

Note: Because Places utilizes the OpenStreetMap tagging scheme internally, you will see many references and links to OpenStreetMap documentation below. Rest assured that edits made in the Places Editor, however, go directly into the internal National Park Service Places database and not into the larger OpenStreetMap database.

Start Mapping Now!

Must be on the NPS network.

Points of Interest

Point feature

Description
A point of interest or "POI" is represented by a point or "node" on the map and has geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude). A POI can be a standalone node or it can be part of a "way" (an ordered list of nodes representing a linear feature or area). Learn more about POIs from the OpenStreetMap wiki.
How to Map
Add a point of interest using Places Editor's "Point" tool to create a point on the map and select the appropriate preset from the "Select feature type" menu.
POI Types
Places supports a wide variety of POIs, a full list of which can be found in our data preset wiki (NPS-only). This guide is intended to serve as a starting point for contributing to Places, so we are only going to review some of the most common/basic points of interest to add to the map. Don't see the feature you're looking for? Open an issue on GitHub.

Campground Campsite Lodge Picnic Area Restroom Waste Basket Trailhead Visitor Center Information Ranger Station Entrance Station Telephone Food Service Store Gas Station Drinking Water Boat Launch Park District

Campground
Description
A campground is an area, usually divided into a number of pitches (or "campsites"), where people can camp overnight using tents or camper vans or caravans. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a campground by creating a point in the middle of the area and selecting "Campground" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • tourism=camp_site
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=
  • opening_hours=
  • capacity=
  • fee=

Campsite
Description
A campsite is an individual pitch within a campground where people can camp overnight using tents or camper vans or caravans. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a campsite by creating a point in the middle of the pitch and selecting "Campsite" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • tourism=camp_site
  • camp_site=pitch
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=
  • opening_hours=
  • capacity=
  • fee=

Lodge
Description
A lodge or "alpine hut" is a remote building located in the mountains intended to provide board and lodging. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a lodge by creating a point on top of the associated building and selecting "Lodge" from the "Select feature type" menu. Additionally, trace the building footprint if it has not been added (see the buildings section to learn more about tracing building footprints).
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • tourism=alpine_hut
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=
  • opening_hours=

Picnic Area
Description
A picnic area is an area that is suitable for outdoors eating and may have a number of facilities to aid a picnic: tables, benches, restrooms, grills, water taps, covered pavilions, etc. Or, it may just be a grassy area popular for picnics. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a picnic area by creating a point in the middle of the area and selecting "Picnic Area" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • tourism=picnic_site
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=
  • opening_hours=
  • fee=

Restroom
Description
A restroom is a restroom facility or "toilet" open to the public. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a restroom by creating a point on top of the associated building and selecting "Restroom" from the "Select feature type" menu. Additionally, trace the building footprint if it has not been added (see the buildings section to learn more about tracing building footprints).
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • amenity=toilets
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=
  • opening_hours=
  • toilets:disposal==
  • male=
  • female=
  • unisex=
  • indoor=
  • access=

Waste Basket
Description
A waste basket is a single small container for depositing garbage that is easily accesible for pedestrians. Similar expressions: rubbish bin, litter bin, trash can, garbage can. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a waste basket by creating a point on top of the container and selecting "Waste Basket" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • amenity=waste_basket
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=
  • waste=
  • bin=

Trailhead
Description
A trailhead is the point at which a trail begins, where the trail is often intended for hiking, biking, skiing, snowshoeing, snowmobiling, horseback riding, or off-road vehicles. It is currently a proposed feature, with no official OSM wiki available.
How to Map
Add a trailhead by creating a point at the start of the trail and selecting "Trailhead" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • highway=trailhead
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • tracktype=
  • surface=
  • width=
  • incline=
  • mtb:scale=
  • mtb:scale:uphill=
  • mtb:scale:imba=
  • sac_scale=
  • trail_visibility=
  • access=
Approved Uses
If the trail is intended for specific uses, add the appropriate "Approved Use" using the "Approved Uses" form in the "Edit feature" menu:

  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • motor_vehicle=*
  • motorcycle=*
  • foot=*
  • bicycle=*
  • atv=*
  • 4wd_only=*
  • snowmobile=*
  • horse=*

Visitor Center
Description
A visitor center is a building housing information for visitors, typically including some or all of the following: information resources, facilities (e.g. restrooms, drinking water), ranger staff, and exhibits. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a visitor center by creating a point on top of the associated building and selecting "Visitor Center" from the "Select feature type" menu. Additionally, trace the building footprint if it has not been added (see the buildings section to learn more about tracing building footprints).
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • tourism=information
  • information=office
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=
  • opening_hours=

Information
Description
Information is an information source for visitors, typically an informational board. This is the default and most basic information-related tag, which can be added in more specific forms such as a visitor center or information map. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add information by creating a point on top of the amenity and selecting "Information" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • tourism=information
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=
  • opening_hours=

Ranger Station
Description
A ranger station is a building or facility primarily intended to house park law enforcement and rescue staff, and is typically not open to the public. It can also be as simple as a ranger sitting at a campground kiosk. Ranger stations can be seasonal, and they are commonly confused with visitor centers as both can be located in the same building. Learn more from the OSM wiki, but keep in mind that definitions can vary between the Park Service and Forest Service, and between parks.
How to Map
Add a ranger station by creating a point on top of the associated building and selecting "Ranger Station" from the "Select feature type" menu. In the event the station is co-located with a visitor center, the best practice is to create two coincident points - one for the station and another for the VC.Additionally, trace the building footprint if it has not been added (see the buildings section to learn more about tracing building footprints).
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • amenity=ranger_station
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=
  • opening_hours=

Entrance Station
Description
An entrance station is an official entry point into a park. Learn more from the OSM wiki, but keep in mind that the wiki describes a generalized take while we are targeting official park entrances.
How to Map
Add an entrance station by creating a point on top of the entrance and selecting "Entrance Station" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • barrier=entrance
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=
  • opening_hours=

Telephone
Description
A telephone is a phone available for public use, typically a pay phone on a stand or wall. It may be indoors or outdoors. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a telephone by creating a point on top of the telephone and selecting "Telephone" from the "Select feature type" menu. Where several telephones are arranged side by side, arrange several similar points side by side.
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • amenity=telephone
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=
  • indoor=

Food Service
Description
Food service is also commonly referred to as a food court. It is typically an indoor area within a facility that houses multiple food vendors and provides a common area for dining. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add food service by creating a point on top of the associated building and selecting "Food Service" from the "Select feature type" menu. Additionally, trace the building footprint if it has not been added (see the buildings section to learn more about tracing building footprints).
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • amenity=food_court
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=
  • opening_hours=

Store
Description
A store is a general store, typically selling things like tools, building supplies, clothes, food, and similar items. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a store by creating a point on top of the associated building and selecting "Store" from the "Select feature type" menu. Additionally, trace the building footprint if it has not been added (see the buildings section to learn more about tracing building footprints).
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • shop=general
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=
  • opening_hours=

Gas Station
Description
A gas station is a facility where vehicles can be refueled. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a gas station by creating a point on top of it and selecting "Gas Station" from the "Select feature type" menu. If the gas station includes a building housing a store, see the store section above to learn how to add it. Additionally, trace the building footprint if it has not been added (see the buildings section to learn more about tracing building footprints).
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • amenity=fuel
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=
  • opening_hours=

Drinking Water
Description
Drinking water is a location at which potable water is available for consumption. Typically this comes in the form of a water fountain. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add drinking water by creating a point on top of the amenity and selecting "Drinking Water" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • amenity=drinking_water
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • description=
  • indoor=
  • access=

Boat Launch
Description
A boat launch is a ramp into the water used to launch a boat, also referred to as a slipway, boat ramp, or boat landing. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a boat launch by creating a point in the middle of the ramp and selecting "Boat Launch" from the "Select feature type" menu.
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • leisure=slipway
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • whitewater=
  • width=
  • section_grade=
Approved Water Uses
If the boat launch is intended for specific uses, add the appropriate "Approved Use" using the "Approved Water Uses" form in the "Edit feature" menu. Use "Canoe" for non-motorized watercraft and "Motorboat" for motorized watercraft. Learn more about water trails in the trail section here.

  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • canoe=*
  • motorboat=*

Park District
Description
A park district or "locality" is, generally speaking, a region of a park that has a name. This can come in a variety of forms including an official park administrative unit, a named region of a park, or a city/town neighborhood. Learn more from the OSM wiki, but keep in mind that the wiki describes the OSM-specific context, while we have our own adoption of this for NPS.
How to Map
Add a park district by creating a point in the middle of the associated area and selecting "Park District" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • place=locality
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • population=

Buildings

Area feature

Description
Buildings in Places are intentionally simple. We are primarily concerned with building footprints, while any additional building amenities are added as points of interest on top of the footprint (see the points of interest section to learn more).
How to Map
Add a building footprint by using the "Area" tool to trace the building footprint and select "Building" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • building=yes
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • addr=
  • building:levels=

Note: Don't get too carried away with nodes while tracing - keep it simple to conform to the general shape of the building visible from the imagery. More nodes mean more data, which can ultimately slow the database.

Additionally, if you know the location of the building's entrance or exit you can add it as a vertex on the building footprint polygon. Add a building entrance/exit by creating a point at the appropriate location and selecting "Entrance/Exit" from the "Select feature type" menu. Learn more from the OSM wiki here.

  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • building=entrance
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=

Roads

Line feature

Description
Generally speaking, a road is intended primarily for use by motorized vehicles. Sidewalks are also included in this section, which of course are an exception to this rule. Learn more about roads from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a road by using the "Line" tool to trace its centerline from beginning to end and selecting the appropriate preset from the "Select feature type" menu. If a road's classification is unknown, default to the "Unclassified Road" preset.
Road Types/Attributes
Places supports a variety of road classifications, outlined below. Basic road attributes are also outlined here including surface type, directionality, lanes, and speed limit along with how to handle intersections.

Primary Road Secondary Road Residential Road Unclassified Road Service Road Bridge Tunnel Sidewalk Intersections Surface One Way Lanes Speed Limit

Primary Road
Description
A primary road is a major highway, normally with two lanes. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a primary road by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Primary Road" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • highway=primary
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • surface=
  • width=
  • maxspeed=
  • oneway=
  • lanes=
  • access=

Secondary Road
Description
A secondary road is a highway that is not part of a major route but forms a link in the national route network. It usually has two lanes, separated by a centerline. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a secondary road by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Secondary Road" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • highway=secondary
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • surface=
  • width=
  • maxspeed=
  • oneway=
  • lanes=
  • access=

Residential Road
Description
A residential road is a road that accesses residential areas but is not a classified or unclassified highway. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a residential road by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Residential Road" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • highway=residential
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • surface=
  • width=
  • maxspeed=
  • oneway=
  • lanes=
  • access=

Unclassified Road
Description
An unclassified road is a minor public road, typically at the lowest level of the interconnecting network. It is of lower importance than a secondary road and is not a residential street. If a road's classification is unknown, default to the "Unclassified Road" preset. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add an unclassified road by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Unclassified Road" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • highway=unclassified
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • surface=
  • width=
  • maxspeed=
  • oneway=
  • lanes=
  • access=

Service Road
Description
A service road is a road accessing a building, service station, beach, campsite, business park, parking lot, driveway, etc. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a service road by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Service Road" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • highway=service
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • surface=
  • width=
  • maxspeed=
  • oneway=
  • lanes=
  • access=
  • service=

Bridge
Description
A bridge is a structure used to carry a road, railway, or similar feature over another feature. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a bridge by splitting the upper way at each end of the bridge (where it joins solid ground) and selecting "Bridge" from the "Structure" form in the "Edit feature" menu. Remember to maintain the road's existing classification, e.g. "Primary Road."
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • bridge=yes
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=

Tunnel
Description
A tunnel is an underground or underwater passageway enclosed except for its entrance and exit at each end. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a tunnel by splitting the enclosed section of the way and selecting "Tunnel" from the "Structure" form in the "Edit feature" menu. Remember to maintain the road's existing classification, e.g. "Primary Road."
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • tunnel=yes
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=
  • opening_hours=

Sidewalk
Description
A sidewalk is a part of a road dedicated for pedestrian use, usually separated from the road by a curb. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a sidewalk by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting the "Sidewalk" preset from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • highway=footway
  • footway=sidewalk
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • surface=
  • lit=
  • width=
  • access=
Crosswalk
If the sidewalk crosses a road, forming a crosswalk, add it by selecting "Crosswalk" from the "Structure" form in the "Edit feature" menu:

  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • crossing=yes

Intersections
Description
An intersection occurs where two or more roads meet. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
To create a simple intersection between two roads, remember to connect them with a node at the point of intersection.

Surface
Description
Surface describes the physical surface of a feature (in this case, a road or trail). Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a road's surface by selecting the associated way and choosing the appropriate surface type from the "Surface" form in the "Edit feature" menu:

  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • surface=*

One Way
Description
Oneway indicates the oneway access restriction on roads. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add oneway access by selecting the associated way and clicking "Assumed to be No" in the "One Way" form of the "Edit feature" menu, which will change to "Yes" after selection. Note that ways have a directionality, so the direction in which you map the way determines its directionality. However, you can change the oneway=yes tag to oneway=-1 in the "All tags" table of the "Edit feature" menu to reverse its existing directionality (appropriate when a way's directionality already governs another attribute such as a bus route).

  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • oneway=*

Lanes
Description
Lanes indicate the number of traffic lanes on a highway that are available to motorized traffic (bicycle lanes are therefore excluded). Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Classify the number of lanes a road has by selecting the associated way and entering the appropriate number into the "Lanes" form of the "Edit feature" menu:

  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • lanes=*

Speed Limit
Description
Speed limit indicates the maximum legal speed limit for general traffic on a road. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Classify a road's speed limit by selecting the associated way and entering the appropriate number into the "Speed Limit" form of the "Edit feature" menu, along with the appropriate unit of measure (mph is the default).

  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • maxspeed=*

Trails

Line feature

Description
Generally speaking, a trail is intended primarily for recreational use such as hiking, biking, skiing, etc. Learn more about trails from the OSM wiki, but keep in mind that not all trail type definitions apply across our NPS tagging schema.
How to Map
Add a trail by using the "Line" tool to trace its centerline from beginning to end and selecting the appropriate preset from the "Select feature type" menu. If a trail's classification is unknown, default to the "Non-Motorized Trail" preset. If the classification is unknown but it is known to allow motorized vehicle access, default to the "Motorized Trail" preset.

Note: remember to add a trailhead to the start of each trail, along with the associated approved uses. If a trail crosses a road, forming a crosswalk, use the "Structure" form in the "Edit feature" menu to add the associated way as a "Crosswalk" (see the sidewalk section for more information).

Trail Types
The presets for different trail types will vary, classified below.

Non-Motorized Trail Motorized Track Piste Water Trail

Non-Motorized Trail
Description
A non-motorized trail is intended for non-motorized traffic including pedestrian use ("foot traffic"), biking, or horseback riding. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a non-motorized trail by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Non-Motorized Trail" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • highway=path
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • tracktype=
  • surface=
  • width=
  • incline=
  • mtb:scale=
  • mtb:scale:uphill=
  • mtb:scale:imba=
  • sac_scale=
  • trail_visibility=
  • access=
Approved Uses
If the trail is intended for specific uses, add the appropriate "Approved Use" using the "Approved Uses" form in the "Edit feature" menu:

  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • foot=*
  • bicycle=*
  • horse=*

Motorized Track
Description
A motorized track is permissive to motorized traffic, such as all-terrain and four-wheel drive vehicles, motorcycles, and snowmobiles. A motorized track can be permissive to non-motorized traffic as well, but it must be permissive to motorized traffic to warrant this classification.
How to Map
Add a motorized track by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Motorized Track" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • highway=track
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • tracktype=
  • surface=
  • width=
  • incline=
  • mtb:scale=
  • mtb:scale:uphill=
  • mtb:scale:imba=
  • sac_scale=
  • trail_visibility=
  • access=
Approved Uses
If the trail is intended for specific uses, add the appropriate "Approved Use" using the "Approved Uses" form in the "Edit feature" menu:

  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • motor_vehicle=*
  • motorcycle=*
  • foot=*
  • bicycle=*
  • atv=*
  • 4wd_only=*
  • snowmobile=*
  • horse=*

Piste
Description
A piste is a trail intended for winter sports such as downhill and cross-country skiing, dog sledding, and snowshoeing. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a piste by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting the appropriate preset from the "Select feature type" menu. Note: the "Places Editor Preview" features a downhill ski trail, one of many piste types below.
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • piste:type=hike
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • piste:difficulty=
  • operator=
  • tracktype=
  • surface=
  • width=
  • incline=
  • mtb:scale=
  • mtb:scale:uphill=
  • mtb:scale:imba=
  • sac_scale=
  • trail_visibility=
  • access=
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • piste:type=downhill
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • piste:difficulty=
  • operator=
  • tracktype=
  • surface=
  • width=
  • incline=
  • mtb:scale=
  • mtb:scale:uphill=
  • mtb:scale:imba=
  • sac_scale=
  • trail_visibility=
  • access=
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • piste:type=nordic
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • piste:difficulty=
  • operator=
  • tracktype=
  • surface=
  • width=
  • incline=
  • mtb:scale=
  • mtb:scale:uphill=
  • mtb:scale:imba=
  • sac_scale=
  • trail_visibility=
  • access=
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • piste:type=skitour
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • piste:difficulty=
  • operator=
  • tracktype=
  • surface=
  • width=
  • incline=
  • mtb:scale=
  • mtb:scale:uphill=
  • mtb:scale:imba=
  • sac_scale=
  • trail_visibility=
  • access=
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • piste:type=sleigh
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • piste:difficulty=
  • operator=
  • tracktype=
  • surface=
  • width=
  • incline=
  • mtb:scale=
  • mtb:scale:uphill=
  • mtb:scale:imba=
  • sac_scale=
  • trail_visibility=
  • access=

A piste can also be added as a POI, using the "Point" tool to create a point and selecting the appropriate preset from the "Select feature type" menu.

Water Trail
Description
A water trail is a trail running through a waterway, intended for canoes, kayaks, motorboats, etc. Places supports two types of water trails: "Non-Motorized Watercraft Trail," for a route accessible to non-motorized watercraft such as a canoe or kayak, and "Motorized Watercraft Trail," for a route accessible to motorized watercraft such as a powerboat or motorized sailboat.
How to Map
Add a water trail by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting the appropriate preset from the "Select feature type" menu. Note: the "Places Editor Preview" features a motorized watercraft trail.
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • waterway=yes
  • canoe=yes
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • whitewater=
  • width=
  • section_grade=
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • waterway=yes
  • motorboat=yes
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • whitewater=
  • width=
  • section_grade=

The start and end of a water trail is often a boat launch, which is added as a POI (see the boat launch section for more information).

Parking

Area, Point, and Line feature

Description
Parking takes two primary forms in Places: parking (amenity) (a generic term, indicating parking is available as an amenity, typically in the form of a parking lot or garage) and parking aisles. Learn more from the parking and parking aisle OSM wikis.
How to Map
Add parking by using the "Area," "Point," and/or "Line" tool, depending on the feature type (described below).
Parking Types
Places supports the following parking types:

Parking (amenity) Parking Aisle

Parking (amenity)
Description
Parking is a facility available for use by the public, customers, or other authorized users for the parking of motor vehicles (cars, trucks, motorcycles, etc). This can come in various forms, including a parking lot or garage, among others. Learn more from the OSM wiki.
How to Map
Adding parking is generally a two-step process. If the amenity is a parking lot or garage, add it by tracing the area footprint and selecting "Parking" from the "Select feature type" menu:
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • amenity=parking
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=
  • capacity=
  • maxstay=
  • fee=
  • access=

Next, create a point in the center of the area and select "Parking" from the "Select feature type" menu to add it as a POI. If the parking area is undefined simply add the point without defining an area.

  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • amenity=parking
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • operator=
  • addr=
  • capacity=
  • maxstay=
  • fee=
  • access=

Parking Aisle
Description
A parking aisle is a subordinated way in a parking lot between rows of parking spaces that vehicles use to drive into and out of the spaces. Learn more from OSM wiki.
How to Map
Add a parking aisle by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Parking Aisle" from the "Select feature type" menu. The main way(s) in the parking lot, for entering and connecting multiple parking aisles, should be tagged as service roads.
  • The underlying preset tag(s):
  • highway=service
  • service=parking_aisle
  • Add additional information using these optional fields:
  • name=
  • surface=
  • oneway=
  • access=
